description: Values of pi(x) where x exceeds n * pi(x).
comments: "Exceeds" can be interpreted as ">" or ">=" since the corresponding primes are never multiples of their indices. - _R. J. Mathar_, Jun 08 2008Equivalently, a(n) = minimal k such that prime(k)/k >= n. - _Enoch Haga_, Oct 19 2007a(n) = A090974(n) = A062742(n) = A038606(n) for n >= 3. [From _Jaroslav Krizek_, Dec 13 2009]
example: x exceeds 3*pi(x) when pi(x)=12, so a(3)=12
mathematica: Join[{k = 1}, Table[While[Prime[k]/k < n, k++]; k, {n, 2, 18}]] (* _Jayanta Basu_, Jul 10 2013 *)
author: _Jud McCranie_
extensions: a(24)-a(28) from _Robert G. Wilson v_, Sep 26 2005
Edited by _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jun 30 2008 at the suggestion of R. J. Mathar.
